text.title: Dynasty: Wei 魏 to Tang 唐 (220–907 CE)
text.content: Script Name: Regular Script (楷书, Kǎishū) became fully developed by the Tang Dynasty and remains the most standardized and widely used script in modern Chinese. It is known for its precision, clarity, and balanced structure.

text.title: Key Characteristics
text.content: Clear and Defined Strokes: Each stroke is carefully separated and distinct, making Regular Script easy to read and highly legible.
Standardized Form: Characters are well-proportioned with consistent rules for stroke order and spacing.
Balanced Structure: Regular Script is balanced and symmetrical, with attention to detail in each stroke's thickness and angle.

text.title: Body:
text.content: The body is compact, rectangular, and evenly proportioned, with each stroke meticulously placed.

text.title: Tail:
text.content: The tail is two short, symmetrical strokes at the bottom, positioned with precision for a balanced look.

text.title: Fins:
text.content: The fins are small horizontal lines on either side, distinct and well-placed to maintain clarity.

text.title: Head and Eye:
text.content: The eye is a small dot or line near the top, subtle but clearly defined, adding to the character’s clean and organized appearance.
